title: Quiz 3: Trial of Labour & Induction
topicName: Unit Three Part Two : Abnormal Labour and Puerperium
description: Coverage of trial of labour management, induction methods, and prolonged/obstructed labour.

questions.question: A Bishop Score of 6 or more indicates that:

richContent.content:
FeatureScore 0Score 1Score 2
DilationClosed1-2cm3-4cm
Effacement0-30%40-50%60-70%

options.text: The cervix is unfavourable; induction will fail
The cervix is favourable; induction is likely to succeed

questions.explanation: A Bishop Score â‰¥ 6 indicates a favourable cervix, meaning the induction of labour has a high probability of success.
questions.hint: Higher score = softer, more open cervix.

questions.question: Which of the following are contraindications for a Trial of Labour? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Trial of labour is avoided if the risk of rupture or failure is high, such as in severe contracture, malpresentations, or multiple previous scars.
questions.hint: Think about conditions that make vaginal delivery dangerous or impossible.

questions.question: Match the sign of obstructed labour to its stage:

pairs.right: Presenting part remains high despite good contractions

questions.explanation: Early signs involve lack of progress; late signs involve physical changes like the retraction ring and systemic distress.
questions.hint: Bandl's ring is a sign of imminent rupture.

questions.question: Prolonged labour is defined as established labour that exceeds ___BLANK___ hours.
questions.explanation: Traditionally defined as >24 hours, but modern active management considers >12 hours of established labour as prolonged.
questions.hint: Think of a standard 12-hour shift or a full day.

questions.question: Order the steps in managing a Trial of Labour:

items.text: Assess pelvic adequacy and foetal size
Monitor contractions and foetal heart rate closely
Ensure adequate hydration and bladder emptying
Terminate trial if foetal/maternal distress occurs

questions.explanation: Assessment -> Monitoring -> Supportive Care -> Decision to terminate if needed.
questions.hint: Safety and monitoring are constant, termination is the endpoint.

questions.question: In a 'Trial of Scar' (VBAC), induction of labour using oxytocin is considered very safe and is routinely recommended.
questions.explanation: Induction with oxytocin in a scarred uterus carries a risk of rupture and must be used with extreme caution or avoided; it is not 'routinely recommended' without strict criteria.
questions.hint: Think about the strength of the scar tissue against strong induced contractions.

questions.question: Which of the following is a sign of 'Maternal Distress'?

options.text: Pulse rate > 120 bpm, dry tongue, ketosis

questions.explanation: Maternal distress presents with tachycardia (>120), dehydration (dry tongue), oliguria (not polyuria), and ketoacidosis.

questions.question: What is the procedure called where membranes are artificially ruptured to induce labour?
questions.explanation: Amniotomy or ARM (Artificial Rupture of Membranes) is the surgical method of induction.

questions.question: What are the indications for Induction of Labour? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Induction is done when continuing pregnancy is risky (post-term, pre-eclampsia, death). Transverse lie and placenta praevia are contraindications requiring C-section.
questions.hint: Conditions where vaginal delivery is possible but needs to start now.

questions.question: Foetal distress is indicated by a foetal heart rate persistently above 160 bpm or below 120 bpm.
questions.explanation: Tachycardia (>160) and Bradycardia (<120) are classic signs of foetal distress.
